content:
Edited to improve the overall formatting, the specifications (in particular T lines of outputs, not N) and the stub (loopline for the choices).

Could you please consider using box-drawing chars for the drawings?
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Box-drawing_character
It would be much cleaner and readable.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I solved this, and this was so fun! I accepted this contribution.

You mix computer science syntax with other syntax. If you want to be clear, you could add labels like this:
      _ _
2 |C C|
1 |C C|
      -  -
      1 2

Otherwise its pretty much accepted that 0,0 represents the top left corner.

If you changed that I would approve it. Also the input statement:

Line 3 An array choices of values between 1 and N inclusive, corresponding to the column choices of Bugs.

Should be replaced by:

Line 3 T space separated integer "choices" 

And then you should remove the second part of the original statement and put it into the constraints as:

1 <= choices <= N

or

choices will always be in [1,N]

etc.

If you make some of those changes I would reconsider approving your contribution.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fine contribution

1) hard not easy lol
2) u said 3rd input is an ARRAY but it's actually a STRING
3) in your example, j is the HIGHEST value for which there is a carrot, if it really were the smallest, the garden will look like this after the first carrot:
  _
|C|X   <-- i= 2(second column), j=1 (1st row)
      _
|C C|
  _  _
The same problem I posted as a Coc, but it was a general opinion that it was too hard to solve in 15 minutes, so here it is as a Classic Puzzle.

Thank you for your suggestions and not downvoting without any explanation as other people :)
If I may respond to those points:

1) It really is easy lol
2) Of course it is passed as a string, but that string represents an array, if you want to use it as an array or not, it's completely up to you but it is highly recommended you do.
3) I used cartesian coordinates to depict the problem so j=0 would be the lowest row. The reason I didn't specify it is because it doesn't matter, so you can use whatever definition you want.

Also you should put in something about whether the garden can be split into separate partitions. Does

CXC

have 8 perimeters? Or is it 9? Or will this not happen in the test cases?
I didn't even know that existed, will take a look and change the drawings when I have the time :)
Hello, and sorry for the late reply. I did have a look at the drawing chars but it does not look better (or I'm just dumb and did not use the right ones)

Here is an example (for the second figure of the statement) using the simplest chars (found in the first section, or in the DOS subset, of the wikipedia link):
https://bin.infini.fr/?31d410a14c074964#Fj57iFwpeBDmjzBH1vAEvc9koanCfyoenz6C9FnyhiTJ
It does not look perfect there, but it will look good on CG (in monospace areas), as it does in the statement of this puzzle for instance:
https://www.codingame.com/training/hard/nonogram-inversor
also, "there will never be a case where choices occurs more than N times" would be a good touch

I'm trying to refrain from use said labels because I really think it is over complicating. As long as "i" is the column and "j" is the row, the output will always be the same. I can see that it might be a problem for several players, so I will change "smallest" to "highest" in the statement, that should make the example clearer :)
Nice suggestion for the array part, and the last comment aswell, definitely an upgrade.

Lastly, I'm not understanding your question about the perimeter. The carrots make 2 squares each with side 1, so the perimeter should be 8. Can you explain me how you think it could be 9?

I rethought this but just so you know what I was thinking:

CCC is:

   ___
 |___| = 8

CXC:
  _      _
|_|_|_| = 9

or
  _     _
|_| |_| = 8

But yeah its a stretch to think that it could be 9.

It is quite a stretch for sure xD
But again, thanks for the suggestions and for giving it a thought
